Addressed the comments. Thanks

Some good points in here but any reason you didn't follow the flow of https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/design-template.md? Starting with the problem description would flow a lot better.
Sure, fixed the flow. Thanks.

This doesn't seem like a great idea.  Why do we need an updater repo per device?  Surely there's some ability to share code?  What about adding to the existing update repo with the new design, and deleting the old updater when the new one has feature parity?

For BMC code update, we can update the existing phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt to reflect the new design. Even currently, we have different repos for psu and pnor (phoshpor-psu-code-mgmt, phosphor-pnor-code-mgmt). Probably we can have one repo per component category (for example, phosphor-vr-code-mgmt for VR) but in general we don't see much code sharing (even within same category) as only shared piece will be the DBus interface which already reside in a common repository (phosphor-dbus-interfaces). Please let me know your thoughts?

> For BMC code update, we can update the existing phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt to reflect the new design. Even currently, we have different repos for psu and pnor (phoshpor-psu-code-mgmt, phosphor-pnor-code-mgmt). Probably we can have one repo per component category (for example, phosphor-vr-code-mgmt for VR) but in general we don't see much code sharing (even within same category)

Really?  This doesn't seem accurate.  All i2c devices are pretty likely to share wrappers around libi2c.  What you're saying is also the opposite of what we've seen in dbus-sensors with regards to VRs, where the majority of code is common, and only the last few lines of the specific commands changes per device, while the transports retries, etc all remain the same.  How did you come to the conclusion that the per-device code would differ significantly?

> as only shared piece will be the DBus interface which already reside in a common repository (phosphor-dbus-interfaces). Please let me know your thoughts?

Done.

As discussed in another comment i have updated the design to mention transport level repositories.
Didn't make it to the design section, but I figure fast feedback is better than complete feedback.
Thanks for the review Ed. Addressed your comments and added responses. Thanks
Nit, this can be removed, we're in the requirements section.  There's no need for a preface.
Ack

This can mean either:
1. I want to update my firmware immediately.
2. I want to update my firmware at a given time.

If you meant #1, you might want to use a word other than schedule.  Maybe start?
If you meant #2, we need more details on how the scheduling aspect will work.

Here the semantics of schedule is either immediately or on reset and its defined in update settings in next line. Update settings basically maps to applySettings in Redfish schema, but for now i am only considering these 2 options (immediately or onReset). I think other options related to maintenance window can be managed outside BMC, so our implementation don't need to consider them. Please let me know if you have any concerns or still think we should change the name.
Lets get that written down.  The term "schedule" is overloaded.
Done. Changed the wording to start as we discussed on code update interface PR.
I don't see this covered in the design.  Does this assume a host reset?  Or the device in questions reset?
My understanding is that this is a device specific detail, i.e. does image apply need a device or host reset and we don't need to cover it in design.
Done
nit, these can be condensed into one.
Ack
nit, the requirement here is "Unprivileged daemons with only access to dbus should be able to perform, and accept a firmware update".
Ack
What is "timely" give it a number (1 second?)
Sure, gave it a 3 second window .
.... using the most applicable Redfish error message.
I don't think we should tailor this requirement specifically for Redfish. For any other client like IPMI it should work accordingly.
nit, "hardware vendors".  OpenBMC vendors should be using the same image format.

Changed Vendors to Hardware Vendors.

Image format related -
1. openBMC image would definitely use the same image format.
2. Hardware vendors for CPLD, NIC, VR should be able to use image format of their choice. So, this requirement is in relation to that.

Moved the Requirement#7 up and changed the wording as below to make it explicit

"Hardware vendors shall be able to choose any image format for their component with no imposition to use generic or single one."
nit, be consistent in your casing.  CPLD, NIC, BIOS, BIC, PCIe etc.  As is you're inconsistent.
Ack

Please remove.  At the moment nobody is owning multi-host support in redfish, despite several requests for ownership, and an approved design.  Lets get single-system firmware update working with multiple devices, then multi-host redfish (or vice versa order if you'd rather).  Doing both at the same time is going to basically guarantee that your patches can't land because they will break some behavior.
After discussing with Patrick i have changed this requirement to "Able to update multiple devices of same type residing on the board" since that is already part of current single host architecture.
and sensor scanning.
The current design doesn't consider sensor scanning as a requirement. Refer to my next comment for more details.
Done
This requirement doesn't look covered by your design.

This requirement is covered under "Uninterrupted Updates" section in design. 

As mentioned in my previous comment current design doesn't consider "sensor scanning" as a requirement, but if needed we can rename ActivationBlocksTransitions to something more generic so it can serve as a indication to not perform certain actions when update is in flight.

> This requirement is covered under "Uninterrupted Updates" section in design. 
> 
> As mentioned in my previous comment current design doesn't consider "sensor scanning" as a requirement, but if needed we can rename ActivationBlocksTransitions to something more generic so it can serve as a indication to not perform certain actions when update is in flight.

Need more details on how ActivationBlocksTransitions would solve this problem.  Stopping sensor scanning while firmware updates are in progress is a pretty common requirement across devices.  I asked more questions on that comment, so I'm closing this one.
Done.

It would help quite a bit if you could push this somewhere (probably your personal github) where this can be rendered.  It's basically impossible to review in code review.

Is there a way to #include this in markdown (I don't know if there is) so this file is less cluttered?

I did some digging, but sorry, couldn't find a tag in markdown which has native support for it.

Sure, i have pushed it here https://github.com/jagpalgill/Code-Update/blob/main/Proposed-Design.md

I have no interest in supporting two different APIs in bmcweb.  We've done this in the past, and it lead to problems.  Please plan on building a complete replacement for what exists.  If there's some amount of rollout plan you'd like to execute, I'm happy to discuss and see a timeline for that (including suggested periods that include testing and deletion of the old code), but as written, this lists some dubious "stability" timelines, that in the past have caused problems with lack of ownership post-acceptance (virtual media, multi-host redfish), when nobody wanted to test or make sure the new stack was stable to the old user-facing APIs.

As mentioned, the long term goal is not to have two different code stacks but just one. But i don't think doing a complete switchover in one go is possible and even advisable. And yes, as you mentioned there would need to be a rollover period for this across multiple daemons but in interim period we may support 2 code flows.

> As mentioned, the long term goal is not to have two different code stacks but just one. But i don't think doing a complete switchover in one go is possible and even advisable.

At no point did I say "in one go", I asked for a "timeline" that showed a progression, including who was going to own the steps.  If there's a plan to get everyone moved over to the new one, lets get that written down.  If the plan is to keep two sets of code around forever (like happened in a couple other cases in the past, and I now get to maintain) that won't get my support.

> And yes, as you mentioned there would need to be a rollover period for this across multiple daemons but in interim period we may support 2 code flows.

Done.

Fixed and added more details on ownership.
Any user-api facing impacts?  Even if the goal is to not have any user facing API impacts, explicitly listing that would be a good idea.
Ack
You've omitted "Who will be the initial maintainer(s) of this repository?"  This is arguably the most important organizational question, given that person will be responsible for the code.
Added the section.
This is deprecated.  I'm pretty sure you meant webui-vue?

NOTE: I derived this list from doing code search and checking what uses the existing code-update interface. So, yes based on below comment in Readme for "phosphor-webui" it would have been webui-vue, but i don't see webui-vue using the code-update interface, hence dropping it from list.

"webui-vue repository is a replacement for phosphor-webui."
?  What is going in openbmc-tools?  If it's the "execute update over redfish" code, then please put it into one of the DMTF Redfish libraries or applications, rather than creating a new one.
It was mostly related to incorporate any changes related to https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc-tools/blob/cff0bfa003d9f8a2f12f13c9b80646315c6f6b8c/openbmctool/openbmctool.py#L397

This is a very old tool that was used as a bridge between our transition from IPMI to the REST api to Redfish. I'd be fine if you just list an assumption that this will not be supported with this new design as everyone should just be using redfish directly at this point.
+1 to Andrews comment.  openbmctool uses the Rest API, which is deprecated.
Done.
This is also deprecated.  Nothing uses phosphor-rest-server anymore now that bmcweb has taken over.
Sure, will drop it.
I'll try to review over the next few days but wanted to ask the flow charts hosting.
Thanks
Thanks. Replied to your comments.
please host this reference in the project

Gerrit doesn't process the mermaid diagrams but github can. But we cannot push to openbmc github without approval and also this is a depiction i have created for existing flow for review comparison purpose.

Hence, for now i have committed this to my personal github and added a link for it in design doc. I am going to remove this link before commit or if needed we can add the actual mermaid diagram (before commit).

Jagpal, there isn't any need to give links outside of Github.  Once you upload a commit to Gerrit it is sync'd to Github (even pre-merge).

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/387e6332fd3eb9337b083942e844abcce4a01177/designs/code-update.md

Done.

ohh great. Will use this link for proposed design. For anyone interested in existing flow, i am adding a link here for reference since existing flow won't be part of design doc.

https://github.com/jagpalgill/Code-Update/blob/main/Current-Design.md
please host in the project (create or include in gerrit or OpenBMC GitHub) and make URL link

Gerrit cannot process the mermaid diagrams and it was hard for folks to review, thats the reason i have put this in my personal github. It was a suggestion by Ed Taneous. We will remove this link before commit as openBMC github will be able to process the mermaid diagram.

I wonder if we need a requirement to support devices that have primary/backup designs. For example, some systems have 2 flash chips for BMC firmware. Some have a single emmc that it is carved up into 2 copies. Is that all abstracted by the service implementing the update?

> I wonder if we need a requirement to support devices that have primary/backup designs.

We could add the requirement, but this feels device specific, and unimportant to this level.  I don't know of any "standard" for AB updates, so I suspect each device daemon will implement its own mechanism.

> For example, some systems have 2 flash chips for BMC firmware. Some have a single emmc that it is carved up into 2 copies. Is that all abstracted by the service implementing the update?

Yes.
Yes, i agree with Ed that it looks more of a device specific detail and would be better if device specific daemon handles it as per their fit.

Is there any thought given to being able to package these device images into the BMC image, and then having the BMC code do the device updates after it starts up with an image that contains new versions?  Or at least there wouldn't be a reason that we couldn't write some code to do the updates with these new daemons say when the BMC gets to Ready after a code update?  IBM only ever provides a single image for all of its firmware.

@Matt, I am not sure if providing a new BMC image for updating a related component would be reasonable. This way every such update cycle will result in bumping the BMC version as it will get tied to it. It will also increase the BMC image size. I would let other folks to share their thoughts.

I had discussed this with @Adriana on this. All this already gets handled as part of backend as the required image gets placed at required filesystem path to be used for upgrade after reboot.

Also, as mentioned in design there are no restrictions on any specific image format. Hence, i am marking this comment as resolved for now unless @Matt has any further comments on this.

One thing I missed the first time around, that's kind of implied, but I think should explicitly be called out is the ability to map a given physical component to the update "slot" for that device.  Given that we're going to support multiple devices and not have a custom format that determines what devices an update payload supports, that would mean that a user needs to be able to ask Redfish to implement the UpdateService.Targets property, which would need to have some mapping in dbus (X firmware update API is for Y processor/drive/power supply).

I don't see that called out here.  If you'd rather deal with that in a PDI 
 (and presumably entity-manager) review, that's fine with me.

Done.

Please refer to the update flow sequence diagram. It covers how does a Redfish Target URI gets mapped to the DBus path. I have added a section on Associations in doc for more details on this.
Also the design is not imposing any restriction for any specific image format.

> Also the design is not imposing any restriction for any specific image format.

What i meant: BMC will use a common image format. When i say "not imposing any restriction for any specific image format" i am referring to FW images for other hardware components such as CPLD, NIC etc.
Please don't point to personal repositories in project documents.
Done

We've had memory issues before (our images can be 100MB+ in size). Multiple of these sticking around in memory for parallel updates could be dangerous. Is there any chance of being able to still offload to /tmp and then send the fd to that file to the update services vs. keeping it all in bmcweb memory? Does allowing bmcweb access to /tmp really raise security concerns?

>  Is there any chance of being able to still offload to /tmp and then send the fd to that file to the update services

What does this fix?  /tmp uses ram, so does bmcweb.  In theory it's pretty trivial to write the FD in, say 8k increments so we don't double count memory, but I don't see this as terribly important to this design, but an implementation detail.

I suspect this needs to say "Implementations need to implement appropriate memory limits to prevent parallel updates from running the bmc out of memory."
Done.

Can you give some more details here?  In the simplest case, lets take a power supply that supports PMBUS update, but requires no other commands run to that device while the update is in progress (as is pretty common), how would this interface prevent access to that device from, for example, dbus-sensors?  We likely can't stop ALL sensor scanning, because that would be a thermal problem for the server, so how would this interface know WHICH things to stop scanning?
Done.
I'm a little concerned this could cause a lot of new small repos in openbmc. I'd prefer one large repo where we use the OWNERS file to determine who maintains which sub-directories.

> I'd prefer one large repo where we use the OWNERS file to determine who maintains which sub-directories.

Why?  Isn't this just a monorepo by another name?

I don't expect there to really be a lot of sharing between the update portions of this.  It also gives a clear path for supporting non-opensource updates (which, while not a primary focus of this project, is an unfortunate reality).

I don't really think there is a lot of [code] overlap in update for the BMC, voltage regulators (i2c), NICs (pldm), and CPLDs (JTAG).  Do we really want all these different interfaces, and corresponding access libraries, needing to be linked into a single repository?  What happens if/when various CPLD vendors give us separate libraries for their special flavor of JTAG?

My opinion is that if the interface requires a lot of boiler-code that is copied around various repositories, we've failed in defining the interface.  Let's fix that (if it is a problem) rather than trying to cram everything into one big repo.

> Why? Isn't this just a monorepo by another name?

Yeah, but to me it's much more user-friendly. Wouldn't you prefer to go to one repo to find all of the supported devices for code update by the project vs. trying to find the random repo? Our documentation for repos in openbmc is bad. When the project started we focused on lots of small repos, which caused a lot of confusion IMO. We then started moving towards larger repos (converging on PDI, moving PEL's into logging, ...).
I suggest working with Ed on a proposal for a monorepo then.  We shouldn't debate that in every individual feature design proposal.

> Why? Isn't this just a monorepo by another name?

I don't believe so.  This looks more like dbus-sensors or bmcweb, which centralize one function into a single repo.


FWIW, because these are going to share a transport to whatever device (i2c, pldm, whatever) I would expect the implementations of each to go in the repo that deals with that transport to avoid duplicating code and dependencies.  (i2c devices in dbus-sensors, pldm in pldmd, etc).  To support things like stopping sensor scanning when firmware updates are in progress (as is required by a lot of devices), it helps a lot to have the implementation for a complete device in one daemon.


I share Andrews concerns that:
1. As written going to create a lot of new repositories, and the repo creation overhead today is still high, which will possibly limit the number of devices we can support.  Considering we're likely to support 10s if not 100s of devices, that number of repos doesn't seem wise.
2. This is going to de-incentivize core maintainers to maintain firmware update as a whole, given that each repo will likely have different maintainers (if this isn't the plan, let me know).  This is what we've seen with the IPMI repos that are repo-per-oem.

Also, in the context of this doc, it doesn't seem wise to approve the creation of wildcard repos with no fixed bound or listed maintainers.

I'm fine with transport-level update repositories.  I suspect that pldmd will be one of the primary implementations.  I just don't want to see a direction that _requires_ us to put { i2c, pldm, jtag, spi, BMC, BIOS } updates all in one giant repo.  The "updates interferes with sensor collection" is one good reason why it doesn't belong into a single large repo because then we end up with coordination between ... for example ... dbus-sensors and phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt.

I think Jagpal can adjust the wording to be transport-centric (or device-type-centric) rather than device-centric.  From an OpenBMC perspective we can aim at that.

Hopefully the design still allows proprietary update methods (in non-OSS repositories) because that seems to be something that a number of companies have been interested in.  Typically this is related to custom silicon where there are not public data sheets.  It seems relatively straight-forward for us to come up with a design where they can drop-in their own repositories without having to modify bmcweb, etc.

> I'm fine with transport-level update repositories.  I suspect that pldmd will be one of the primary implementations.  I just don't want to see a direction that _requires_ us to put { i2c, pldm, jtag, spi, BMC, BIOS } updates all in one giant repo.  The "updates interferes with sensor collection" is one good reason why it doesn't belong into a single large repo because then we end up with coordination between ... for example ... dbus-sensors and phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt.
> 
> I think Jagpal can adjust the wording to be transport-centric (or device-type-centric) rather than device-centric.  From an OpenBMC perspective we can aim at that.

Sounds good to me.  This will be a significant improvement.

> 
> Hopefully the design still allows proprietary update methods (in non-OSS repositories) because that seems to be something that a number of companies have been interested in.

I can't see why it would prevent that, and I think it supports that mode.  If it's proprietary, do whatever you want, and reuse/copy whatever transport code you'd like into a private daemon and maintain it.  For upstream, we should avoid copying code for similar transports.

>  Typically this is related to custom silicon where there are not public data sheets.  It seems relatively straight-forward for us to come up with a design where they can drop-in their own repositories without having to modify bmcweb, etc.

Agreed, and I think just having it on dbus supports that, so long as we're using the mapper to look up EM devices that support update.  It's basically the same as the sensor model, which seems to work (there's probably more downstream vendor-specific sensor code than there is upstream at this point).

Done.

Device transport level for repo distribution seems to strike the right balance. Sure, will update the design doc to reflect this.

The intent here is that you actually name the people, and ensure they have appropriate participation stats to maintain this amount of code.  If "Hardware vendors" are going to maintain this, then those hardware vendors need to be on the design doc.  It's really difficult to approve the creation of wildcard repos without a named person as maintainer.

Done.

Added details on repo ownership and modification owner.

We still need a Volunteer for modifications to openpower-pnor-code-mgmt. Probably, will check with anoo or gmills as they are the maintainer for that repo or they can suggest someone.
Thanks for the review. Please see comments addressed/replied.
Addressed comments, please review.
Thanks for the review. Addressed and replied to comments.

Per an offline discussion, there's a use case where it's desired to upload an image and later activate it, which is possible with the existing d-bus interfaces. In order to continue to support this use case, we would need to add support to an additional OperationApplyTime. I suggest "OnStartUpdateRequest", where the image would be staged until the user issued a "StartUpdate" action via the SimpleUpdate command. This option is probably simpler and more flexible than "AtMaintenanceWindowStart" because it doesn't require to specify the time when the update should automatically start.
Done. Also updated the interface to reflect this.
Done

I think after BMCW has the inventory item(s), it needs an association or something to determine what is the code update app for that inventory item. 
A mapper call might also be needed
Done
Need the service here.. Not clear how you got it
Done
Thanks for the review.

I'm having trouble understanding the purpose of this adjective here.

- Clearly the daemon isn't the only entity with dbus access or it would just be talking to itself.
- Clearly the daemon needs to do more than access dbus or it couldn't do the update (ie. it also needs hardware access).

Should we drop that word or does it have some meaning in this context I'm not grasping.

Here the Unprivileged daemons refers to daemons like BMCWeb which are user interfacing. This description was added after a comment from @Ed.

Sure, i can drop the word "sole" as it doesn't seem to be necessary.
Where did this number come from?  That seems rather specific.  Is there some spec that requires this?
It was added as @Ed was looking for a specific number. There is no specific reasoning behind it.
Updated the wording.
There is probably _some_ imposition, such as PLDM-based updates should use PLDM package format, right?  But maybe that isn't a requirement of the overall software design.
I don't think we should mention that restriction here. This restriction should be part of the PLDM based firmware update design from Bonnie.
Updated the wording.

This is worded in a way that probably matches what you intend but someone who really understands the implementation might question.

I think the desire is that bmcweb creates an open file descriptor to a tmpfs location and then immediately deletes it (before writing to it).  This file descriptor is what is passed along.

The image is thus still in tmpfs (and in memory) but inaccessible by any process that doesn't have the file descriptor.

I am not sure what u mean by "immediately deletes it (before writing to it)."

bmcweb would need to open file descriptor and write to it, i am not sure what u meant by deleting it before writing to it?
